summary: adenovirus, equine viral arteritis virus, rabies, bluetongue virus, foot-and-mouth disease virus, influenza A virus, rotavirus, orf virus, bovine papillomavirus, vesicular stomatitis virus, coronavirus, bovine parainfluenza-3 virus, west Nile virus, equine herpesvirus-1 [1], [3], [4] and bovine viral recently developed approaches to virus detection have the potential to further expand understanding of viral disease in animals. many of these approaches are based on non-specific PCR amplification used in conjunction with standard or high-throughput sequencing to identify PCR products. four out of 32 alpaca in an Illinois herd died from an acute respiratory infection. d fluorescent antibodies against several bovine viruses failed to detect a virus in the infected cell cultures. negative staining electron microscopy of frozen and thawed infected MDBK cell culture revealed the presence of numerous, uniformly shaped, non-enveloped virus particles approximately 25 to 30 nm in diameter. image was taken at 100, 000. Size bar is 50 nm. cDNA was amplified by DOP-PCR and the obtained products were analyzed by gel electrophoresis. arrowheads indicate PCR products that were sequenced and shown to be BEV-related. 15 Re the genome of the novel virus was most closely related to EV-F. based on recently changed nomenclature [14]–[16], the genome of the virus was most closely related to EV-F. ly BEV type B) serotypes 1 and 3, with homology to EV-F genome sequences ranging from 75–83% at the genome level. the virus identified in this study has to be considered as type 1. the amino acid homology with serotype 2 viruses was 86–87%, and 79% with serotype 3 and 78% with a serotype 4 possum isolate. as compared with serotype 1, the capsid sequence also was less similar to the partial capsid sequences of the unclassified EV-F viruses from bovine (AY424745) and capped langur species (JX538037), each with 87% amino acid identity. enteroviruses representing the bovine enterovirus (BEV) in species EV-E and EV-F, porcine enterovirus (PEV)/Enterovirus G, and human enterovirus (HEV)/Enterovirus A–D groups are included and species and serotypes are indicated. the amino acid sequences were aligned with the Clustal W program. the amino acid sequences were aligned with the Clustal W program. bootstrap confidence values were determined by 1000 replications. scale bar represents the number of amino acid substitutions per site. the alpaca virus homology with the EV-E 5′ UTR was 75–78%. several attempts to perform enterovirus-specific PCRs were made on RNA extracted from paraffin-embedded lung tissues from the two of the alpaca. in addition we also performed DOP-PCR on RNA extracted from these embedded tissues. some non-specific PCR bands were evident, but sequencing of these PCR products revealed no enterovirus sequences. enteroviruses comprise one of nine genera of picornaviruses. members of the genus include members that infect vertebrates. members of the genus include human pathogenic poliovirus, coxsackieviruses and enteroviruses. recombination of viruses from two EV-F serotypes led to this unusual infection. the isolate has approximately 80–85% homology in its protein sequence to previously described EV-F strains. this is similar to the degree of homology shared among protein sequences from previously sequenced EV-F strains isolated from cattle. alpaca infections include bovine viral diarrhea virus, equine herpesvirus 1 and bluetongue virus. newly introduced animals can potentially carry pathogens that are relatively benign to them, but not to the indigenous fauna. the risk obviously increases if newly introduced and indigenous livestock are kept in close proximity. grossly affected tissues were harvested at necropsy for routine histopathological examination using 10% neutral buffered formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded, hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections. the animals used in this study met the definition of “farm animals” which are not covered by the U.S. Animal Welfare Act (9 CFR 1). the homogenate was clarified by centrifugation at 930 g for 20 min at 4°C. cells adherent to the coverslips were washed once in PBS, then fixed in 100% acetone for 10 min at RT followed by air drying. unless otherwise indicated, the following anti-viral antibodies were obtained. four ml of the clarified supernatant containing 1.25% (final) neutral buffered formalin was subjected to ultracentrifugation (76 k g for 1 hour at 4°C) the pellet subsequently was suspended in 100 l of supernatant, stirred with a wooden stick and vortexed until thoroughly mixed. the digestion was carried out in 83 mM NaC2H3O2, 4.2 mM Mg2SO4 and 25 mM NaCl for 30 min at 37°C. the digested samples were purified by ultracentrifugation through a 2 ml 1 M NaCl, 10 mM Tris/HCl pH 7.5 solution cushion. centrifugation was carried out for 1.5 hrs, at 4°C and 64,000 g in a DOP-PCR products were analyzed and purified by agarose gel electrophoresis. distinct bands were excised, purified and ligated into the pCR4-TOPO® vector (Invitrogen) cDNA was synthesized using MMLV reverse transcriptase and an oligo dT primer. the cDNA was then PCR-amplified with a gene specific primer (GSP) and the universal primer provided in the commercial kit. the 3′ end of the viral genome was sequenced using rapid amplification of cDNA ends. RNA was reverse transcribed into cDNA according to manufacturer's instructions. PCRs for two bovine housekeeping genes, –actin and glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) were performed to verify the nucleic acid amplified. geneBank accession numbers used in the analyses were: Enterovirus F, strain IL/Alpaca KC748420, BEV-A, now EV-E (serotypes 1–4) AF123433, D00214, AF123432, DQ092770, DQ092795, AY508696, AY508697, DQ092794, NC001859, AY462106, and unclassified AY24745 sequences the animals used in this study met the definition of “farm animals”, which are not covered by the U.S. Animal Welfare Act (9 CFR 1). the owner provided permission for these studies. cells adherent to the coverslips were washed once in PBS, then fixed in 100% acetone for 10 min at RT followed by air drying. unless otherwise indicated, the following anti-viral antibodies were obtained from VMRD (Pullman, WA) containing 1.25% neutral buffered formalin was subjected to ultracentrifugation (76 k g for 1 hour at 4°C) the pellet subsequently was suspended in 100 l of supernatant, stirred with a wooden stick and vortexed until thoroughly mixed. the sample was then placed on parafilm and a formvar plastic and carbon-coated copper grid was placed on top of the specimen droplet for 15 minutes. centrifugation was carried out for 1.5 hrs, at 4°C and 64,000 g in a SW60 rotor (Beckman Coulter Inc., Fullerton, CA) the supernatant was carefully removed and the air-dried pellet was resuspended in 350 L RLT+-buffer (Qiagen, Valencia, CA) 5 min at 95°C followed by 5 cycles of 1 min at 94°C, 5 min at 25°C, slow ramping at 0.1°C/sec to 30°C, 4 min at 30°C, slow ramping at 0.1°C/sec to 37°C, 3 min at 37°C, slow ramping at 0.1°C/sec to 42°C, 2 min at 42°C, slow ramping at 0.1°C/sec to 55°C, 55°C for 1 min PCR products were cloned and sequenced as described above. the 3′ end of the viral genome was sequenced using rapid amplification of cDNA ends (RACE) with a commercially available kit. the cDNA was then PCR-amplified with a gene specific primer (GSP) and the universal primer provided in the kit. the digestion was carried out in 83 mM NaC2H3O2, 4.2 mM Mg2SO4, and 25 mM NaCl for 30 min at 37°C. the digested samples were purified by ultracentrifugation through a 2 ml 1 M NaCl, 10 mM Tris/HCl pH 7.5 solution cushion. centrifugation was carried out for 1.5 hrs, at 4°C and 64,000 g in a DOP-PCR reactions contained 1.5 mM MgCl2, 10 mM KCl, 10 mM Tris pH 8.4, 200 M dNTP, 2.4 M DOP primer 5′-CCGACTCGAGINNNNNNTGTGG-3′ (Oligos Etc., Wilsonville, OR) the reactions were carried out with 10 L of template. PCR products were cloned and sequenced as described above. the 3′ end of the viral genome was sequenced using rapid amplification of cDNA ends (RACE) with a commercially available kit. cDNA was synthesized using MMLV reverse transcriptase and an oligo dT primer provided with the commercial kit. the 3′ viral ends were sequenced directly from purified PCR products and from the cloned cDNA to verify the correct sequence. formalin-fixed tissues from alpaca and horses involved in the initial outbreak were formalin-fixed and paraffin embedded (FFPE) for future analysis and histopathology. phylogenetic trees were constructed and viewed using Treeview [42] and Phylip software [43] with bootstrap confidence values determined by 1000 replications. not all of the viral sequences used for analyses contained the complete polyprotein sequences. some do not appear in all of the panels of Figures 4 to 8.
